intents.description: Provide a list of foods for user to select

examples.text: Can you explain something about the International Space Station
give me the definition of literature
tell me about Char kway teow
Tell me something about Star Wars

intents.description: Take the feedback input from user, and store to DB2

values.text: Hello, <? input.text ?>! It's lovely to meet you. How can I help you today?

What do you call a fake noodle?
Ans: An impasta!

Pasta and noodle can be found in the Dried foods section.  Pasta is in Row 4 and Noodles are in Row 5.

Why did the skeleton go to the barbeque?
Ans: To get another rib!

We stock a variety of ribs, both fresh and frozen.  
Fresh ribs can be found in the Fresh Meat section in Row 11.
Frozen ribs can be found in the Frozen Meat section in Row 15.

What is better than a good friend?
Ans: A good friend with a chocolate!

Our chocolates are a favourite with kids.  We stock the traditional brands and some gourmet brands for all occasions.  Normal chocolates can be found in the Diary section in Row 21 and gourmet chocolates can be found in the "Gourmet Food around the World" section in Row 28.

What does Thor wear under his pants?
Ans: Thunderpants!

We don't sell Thunderpants (yet), but if you are looking for human underwear, for Men and Boys, they can be found in Rows 33 and for Women and Girls, they are in Row 36.

What do you call cheese that is not yours?
Ans: Nacho cheese!

We stock a variety of cheeses from many countries.  They can be found in the Diary section in Row 22.

What did the pecan say to the walnut?
Ans: We are friends because we are both nuts!

Nuts can be found in two sections: Nuts for snacks can be found in the Snacks section in Row 23 and nuts for baking needs can be found under the Baking Needs section in Row 7.

Why did the tomato go out with a prune?
Ans: Because he couldn't find a date!

Tomatoes are found in the vegetable section in Row 1 and prunes are found in the Dried Fruits section in Row 9

What kind of shoes can you make with banana peels?
Ans: Slippers!

Bananas can be found in the Fruit section in Row 4 and slippers can be found in the Household section in Row 36.

How do you make apple turnover?
Ans: Push it downhill!

Apple turnovers and other yummy cakes can be found in the Cakes section in Row 8.  Apples and other fruits can be found in the fruits section in Rows 2 and 3.

What do you call a sad strawberry?
Ans: A blueberry

Our fruits are delivered fresh everyday.  Strawberries and blueberries can be found in in the fruits section in Row 3.

What did the butcher say to his customer?
Ans: Pleased to meet you, meat to please you!

We have a wide selection of meats.  
Fresh meats can be found between Rows 11 to 13.
Frozen meats can be found between Rows 14 and 15.
Please visit our on-line store to submit your shopping list
Anything else I can assist you?
Please visit our web site to download your shopping list

Hello, I'm Alice, your virtual Singapore Food recipe assistant. I can tell you more about the different types of food in Singapore and help you look these recipes if you like. 
What shall I call you?
Here are some Singaporean food suggestions.

Nasi Lemak Recipe

Steps

Step 1
To cook the rice, add the rice, coconut milk and lemongrass into a saucepan. Settle the rice evenly into the bottom of the saucepan. Place your finger on top of the rice and add enough water so that the liquid comes up to your first knuckle. Place over a medium-high heat and simmer for 10 minutes or until most of the liquid has evaporated. Then place a lid on and reduce the heat to low and cook for another 2 minutes. Then turn the heat off and allow to sit, covered, for 10 minutes. 

Step 2
For the spicy ikan bilis sambal, soak the dried chillies in hot water for 15 minutes to soften. Drain the chillies squeezing out the excess liquid. Reserve the soaking liquid. 

Step 3
Place the soaked chillies in the bowl of a small food processor along with the fresh chilli, shallot, garlic and shrimp paste. Process until a coarse paste forms.  

Step 4
Heat the oil in a wok over high heat. Add the anchovies and cook, stirring often, for 5 minutes or until crisp. Use a slotted spoon to transfer to a plate lined with paper towel. Add the onion to the pan. Cook, stirring occasionally, for 5 minutes. Transfer to the plate with the anchovies. Add the chilli mixture to the wok. Reduce heat to low. Cook, stirring often for 5 minutes or until the red oil rises to the surface. Add the sugar, tamarind and 2 tablespoons of the chilli soaking liquid. Simmer for 5 minutes or until reduced. Stir in the anchovies and onion. Transfer to a bowl.  

Step 5
When ready to serve, use a fork to fluff up the coconut rice. Serve the rice with the spicy ikan bilis sambal, peanuts, egg, cucumber and ayam goreng (if using). 

Notes:

– Typically, this rice is infused with pandan leaves, but I use lemongrass or ginger slices when I can’t find pandan leaves at my Asian grocery store. You could also just do coconut milk without the extra aromatics. 

– Ikan bilis are a dried anchovy fish that are sold through Asian grocery stores. They can be sold ‘fresh’ frozen (in which case you need to cook them as I have here) or they can be bought shelf-stable and already fried, in which case you can just add them into the sambal without having to fry them first. 

https://www.marionskitchen.com/nasi-lemak/

generic.title: Do you want to see the ingredients of nasi lemak?

values.text:
Nasi Lemak Recipe

Steps

Step 1
To cook the rice, add the rice, coconut milk and lemongrass into a saucepan. Settle the rice evenly into the bottom of the saucepan. Place your finger on top of the rice and add enough water so that the liquid comes up to your first knuckle. Place over a medium-high heat and simmer for 10 minutes or until most of the liquid has evaporated. Then place a lid on and reduce the heat to low and cook for another 2 minutes. Then turn the heat off and allow to sit, covered, for 10 minutes. 

Step 2
For the spicy ikan bilis sambal, soak the dried chillies in hot water for 15 minutes to soften. Drain the chillies squeezing out the excess liquid. Reserve the soaking liquid. 

Step 3
Place the soaked chillies in the bowl of a small food processor along with the fresh chilli, shallot, garlic and shrimp paste. Process until a coarse paste forms.  

Step 4
Heat the oil in a wok over high heat. Add the anchovies and cook, stirring often, for 5 minutes or until crisp. Use a slotted spoon to transfer to a plate lined with paper towel. Add the onion to the pan. Cook, stirring occasionally, for 5 minutes. Transfer to the plate with the anchovies. Add the chilli mixture to the wok. Reduce heat to low. Cook, stirring often for 5 minutes or until the red oil rises to the surface. Add the sugar, tamarind and 2 tablespoons of the chilli soaking liquid. Simmer for 5 minutes or until reduced. Stir in the anchovies and onion. Transfer to a bowl.  

Step 5
When ready to serve, use a fork to fluff up the coconut rice. Serve the rice with the spicy ikan bilis sambal, peanuts, egg, cucumber and ayam goreng (if using). 

Notes:

– Typically, this rice is infused with pandan leaves, but I use lemongrass or ginger slices when I can’t find pandan leaves at my Asian grocery store. You could also just do coconut milk without the extra aromatics. 

– Ikan bilis are a dried anchovy fish that are sold through Asian grocery stores. They can be sold ‘fresh’ frozen (in which case you need to cook them as I have here) or they can be bought shelf-stable and already fried, in which case you can just add them into the sambal without having to fry them first. 

https://www.marionskitchen.com/nasi-lemak/
Anything I can assist you?

Nasi Lemak Ingredients

2 cups jasmine rice 

400g (14 fl oz) can coconut milk 

1 lemongrass stalk 

fried peanuts, to serve 

hard boiled eggs, halved, to serve 

sliced cucumber, to serve 

ayam goreng (Malaysian Fried Chicken), to serve (optional) 

 

Spicy ikan bilis sambal: 

10 dried long red chillies 

2 fresh long red chillis 

2 red shallots, roughly chopped 

1 garlic clove, chopped 

1 tsp shrimp paste 

ź cup peanut oil 

1 cup dried anchovies (also called ikan bilis) 

1 small red onion, sliced onto rings 

1 tbsp brown sugar 

1 tbsp tamarind puree

generic.title: Do you want to see the recipe for Char kway teow?

values.text: Anything else I can assist you with $username?
Anything else I can assist you with?

1. We can show you some well-known Singaporean food recipes and help you buy the ingredients so that you can become the MasterChef in your home
2. We bring the freshest ingredients to you at your convenience.  You can shop with us online wherever you are or come into any one of our physical stores. 
3. As your virtual Singapore Food assistant, I can tell you more about well known Singaporean food and give you their recipes for you to try on your own.  
4. We can show you food jokes to have a relax moment.

Char Kway Teow Recipe

Steps

Step 1
For the chilli paste, soak the dried red chillies in hot water for 15 minutes or until softened. Then use tongs to remove them from the soaking liquid. Reserve the soaking liquid in case you need it when blending. Roughly chop the chillies and place them in the bowl of a food processor. Add the fresh chillies, shallots and salt. Blend until smooth (add a tablespoon of the chilli soaking liquid if your food processor gets stuck).

Step 2
Heat 4 tablespoons of vegetable oil in a frying pan over medium heat. Add the chilli paste and cook, stirring, for about 5 minutes. Transfer the chilli paste to a jar.

Step 3
For the stir-fry sauce, mix the ingredients in a small bowl and set aside for later.

Step 4
Heat 2 tablespoons of vegetable oil in a wok or large frying pan over high heat. Add the garlic and stir-fry for 5 seconds. Then add the Chinese sausage and stir-fry for another 10 seconds. Then add the fishcakes and the prawns. Stir-fry until the prawns are almost cooked. Then add 2 heaped tablespoons (or to taste) of the chilli paste. Toss to combine. Then push the ingredients out to the side of the pan to make room in the middle. Add a tablespoon of oil to the centre of the pan. Then pour in the eggs. Use your spatula to spread the eggs out. Once the eggs are set, toss them around with the remaining ingredients.

Step 5
Now add the noodles and the stir-fry sauce. Stir-fry until well combined. Then toss through the bean shoots and the Chinese chives. Remove from heat and serve.

Notes:
– You’ll have more chilli paste than you need for this recipe. Simply store it in the fridge for up to a month. Use it to add a chilli kick to just about anything…stir-fries, grilled meats or breakfast eggs.
– Chinese sausage, also known as lap cheong is a sweet preserved pork sausage. It can be bought online or from an Asian grocery store.
– Asian fishcakes are available in the fridge or freezer section of any Asian grocery store.

generic.title: Do you want to see the ingredients to cook Char kway teow?

values.text:
Char Kway Teow Ingredients

2 tbsp vegetable oil, plus 1 extra tablespoon

4 garlic cloves, roughly chopped

50g (1.7 oz) thinly sliced Chinese sausage*

50g (1.7 oz) thinly sliced Asian fishcakes*

8 small prawns, peeled and deveined

2 eggs, lightly whisked

350g (12 oz) fresh rice noodles

¼ cup bean shoots

2 stems Chinese garlic chives, cut into batons (alternatively, use spring onion/scallions)


Chilli paste:

50g (1.7 oz) dried red chillies

3 fresh mild red chillies, roughly chopped

3 Asian red shallots, roughly chopped

2 tsp sea salt

4 tbsp vegetable oil
 

Stir-fry sauce:

2 tbsp soy sauce

1 tbsp oyster sauce

2 tsp fish sauce

1 tsp dark sweet soy sauce

1 tsp sugar

¼ tsp ground black pepper

ACE is your favourite local supermarket present in 88 locations all around Singapore.  We bring the freshest ingredients to you at your convenience.  You can shop with us online wherever you are or come into any one of our physical stores. We are open every day including public holidays from 9am to 9pm.
As your virtual Singapore Food assistant, I can tell you more about well known Singaporean food and give you their recipes for you to try on your own.  
You can order the ingredients for these recipes online or buy them in any of our physical stores at your convenience.

Char Kway Teow Recipe

Steps

Step 1
For the chilli paste, soak the dried red chillies in hot water for 15 minutes or until softened. Then use tongs to remove them from the soaking liquid. Reserve the soaking liquid in case you need it when blending. Roughly chop the chillies and place them in the bowl of a food processor. Add the fresh chillies, shallots and salt. Blend until smooth (add a tablespoon of the chilli soaking liquid if your food processor gets stuck).

Step 2
Heat 4 tablespoons of vegetable oil in a frying pan over medium heat. Add the chilli paste and cook, stirring, for about 5 minutes. Transfer the chilli paste to a jar.

Step 3
For the stir-fry sauce, mix the ingredients in a small bowl and set aside for later.

Step 4
Heat 2 tablespoons of vegetable oil in a wok or large frying pan over high heat. Add the garlic and stir-fry for 5 seconds. Then add the Chinese sausage and stir-fry for another 10 seconds. Then add the fishcakes and the prawns. Stir-fry until the prawns are almost cooked. Then add 2 heaped tablespoons (or to taste) of the chilli paste. Toss to combine. Then push the ingredients out to the side of the pan to make room in the middle. Add a tablespoon of oil to the centre of the pan. Then pour in the eggs. Use your spatula to spread the eggs out. Once the eggs are set, toss them around with the remaining ingredients.

Step 5
Now add the noodles and the stir-fry sauce. Stir-fry until well combined. Then toss through the bean shoots and the Chinese chives. Remove from heat and serve.

Notes:
– You’ll have more chilli paste than you need for this recipe. Simply store it in the fridge for up to a month. Use it to add a chilli kick to just about anything…stir-fries, grilled meats or breakfast eggs.
– Chinese sausage, also known as lap cheong is a sweet preserved pork sausage. It can be bought online or from an Asian grocery store.
– Asian fishcakes are available in the fridge or freezer section of any Asian grocery store.

Char Kway Teow Ingredients

2 tbsp vegetable oil, plus 1 extra tablespoon

4 garlic cloves, roughly chopped

50g (1.7 oz) thinly sliced Chinese sausage*

50g (1.7 oz) thinly sliced Asian fishcakes*

8 small prawns, peeled and deveined

2 eggs, lightly whisked

350g (12 oz) fresh rice noodles

¼ cup bean shoots

2 stems Chinese garlic chives, cut into batons (alternatively, use spring onion/scallions)


Chilli paste:

50g (1.7 oz) dried red chillies

3 fresh mild red chillies, roughly chopped

3 Asian red shallots, roughly chopped

2 tsp sea salt

4 tbsp vegetable oil
 

Stir-fry sauce:

2 tbsp soy sauce

1 tbsp oyster sauce

2 tsp fish sauce

1 tsp dark sweet soy sauce

1 tsp sugar

¼ tsp ground black pepper

Here we can show you some well-known Singaporean food recipes and help you buy the ingredients so that you can become the MasterChef in your home!
